summary: This document is a series of forwarded emails from whistleblower Christopher J. Dilorio to various SEC officials and judges, primarily dated between June and December 2020. It details Dilorio's allegations of massive, ongoing SEC corruption, obstruction of justice, and facilitation of financial fraud, specifically related to Knight Capital/Virtu Financial (NITE), Blackstone, and various 'money laundering shell' companies. He appeals a preliminary denial of his whistleblower award and accuses the SEC of creating rules to deny him compensation while protecting powerful entities. This document is a lengthy whistleblower complaint and appeal from Christopher Dilorio to the SEC Office of the Whistleblower (OWB), primarily addressed to Jane Norberg. Dilorio alleges the SEC has used his information (submitted via TCRs since 2011) to both bring and obstruct enforcement actions, while denying him compensation. He details a complex, ongoing scheme involving market maker Knight Capital/Virtu (NITE), UBS (UBSS), and various shell companies (e.g., CGFIA, APCX, IMDS) used for money laundering via abusive naked shorting in the OTC markets. He accuses the SEC of criminal obstruction, covering up for NITE and UBSS, and facilitating a massive fraud on the public.

persons.name: Christopher J. Dilorio
persons.context: The author of the emails, alleging widespread SEC corruption, obstruction of investigations into financial fraud at Knight Capital/Virtu (NITE), and denial of his whistleblower award.

persons.name: Janey
persons.context: Primary recipient of Dilorio's emails; accused of not distributing his whistleblower information within the SEC and being part of the obstruction.

persons.name: Hoecker
persons.context: Repeatedly mentioned as part of the 'grossly corrupt SEC' apparatus that obstructs investigations and facilitates fraud.

persons.name: Jay Clayton
persons.context: Accused of undisclosed conflicts of interest related to his former firm Sullivan & Cromwell (Sull Crom) and its clients like Knight/Virtu, and of facilitating fraud.

persons.name: Jared Fishman
persons.context: Attorney at Clayton's former firm accused of playing a key role in SEC-facilitated criminal obstruction related to Knight/KCG/Virtu transactions.

persons.name: Steve Schwarzman
persons.context: Described as being high on the SEC's 'do not investigate list,' connected to the Knight Capital bailout, the KODK loan, and to Trump, Kushner, and Epstein.

persons.name: Jason New
persons.context: A Blackstone executive on the Eastman Kodak board; involved in the internal investigation of the Kodak loan and linked to the alleged fraud.

persons.name: Anthony Zakel
persons.context: Newly hired Inspector General for the U.S. International Development Finance Corporation (DFC), mentioned in relation to the review of the Kodak loan.

persons.name: Adam Boehler
persons.role: CEO of U.S. International Development Finance Corporation (DFC)
persons.context: Mentioned as the DFC CEO who would be investigated by the new IG, Anthony Zakel, regarding a $765 million loan to Kodak.

persons.name: Doug Cifu
persons.context: CEO of Virtu Financial (which owns NITE); accused of running a criminal enterprise involved in abusive naked shorting and money laundering. Linked to former colleague Lara Shalov Mehraban at the SEC.

persons.name: Lara Shalov Mehraban
persons.context: Accused of having a conflict of interest due to her former employment at Paul Weiss with Doug Cifu and of obstructing investigations into Interactive Brokers and Virtu/NITE.

persons.name: Dick Best
persons.context: Newly promoted SEC official; Dilorio questions whether he criminally obstructed an investigation into Brown Brothers Harriman (BBH) and if he will recuse himself.

persons.name: Joshua Sason
persons.context: Named in a 2019 SEC complaint related to microcap frauds and unlawful offerings via entities like Hanover/Magna. Dilorio claims his TCRs pre-dated this action.

persons.name: Justin Keener
persons.context: A 'bag man' barred by FINRA but allegedly still active; involved in money laundering shells like Blink Charging and linked to World Trade Financial.

persons.name: Michael Farkas
persons.context: CEO of Blink Charging (BLNK), a company Dilorio alleges is a money laundering shell. Accused of being a 'prolific Bag Man' who escaped earlier SEC action.

persons.name: Jonathan Farkas
persons.context: Trump fundraiser and alleged business partner of Jeffrey Epstein; questioned if related to Michael Farkas.

persons.name: David Urban
persons.context: Trump's Pennsylvania campaign manager and board member of NITE and FSD Pharma (HUGE); accused of involvement in SEC-facilitated pump-and-dump schemes.

persons.name: Judge Cave
persons.context: Recipient of Dilorio's emails; Dilorio urges her to treat SEC evidence with skepticism and consider a stay in the Kamensky case.

persons.name: Judge Nathan
persons.context: Recipient of Dilorio's emails alongside Judge Cave; urged to question SEC evidence.

persons.name: Alex Ioffe
persons.context: Former CFO of Interactive Brokers (IBKR) hired by Virtu; his tenure at IBKR overlaps with the period covered in an SEC complaint against IBKR.

persons.name: Bill Richardson
persons.context: Mentioned as linked to Jeffrey Epstein and his Zorro Ranch, and involved with Blink Charging (BLNK).

persons.name: Oleg Firer
persons.context: Described as a 'prolific Bag Man' whose company Acies Corp is linked to money laundering shells and entities like Allied Wallet/WireCard.

persons.name: Barry Honig
persons.context: Named in an SEC complaint (Frost, Honig, et al.) and linked to Jaclin money laundering shells like PRComplete/YESDtc.

persons.name: Carl
persons.context: Addressed in one email regarding an FBI document on money laundering risks; implies Carl previously investigated Dilorio's complaints.

persons.name: Christopher Dilorio
persons.context: The author of the complaint, alleging massive securities fraud, money laundering, and SEC obstruction. He claims to have filed multiple TCRs (Tips, Complaints, and Referrals) with the SEC and FINRA since 2011.

persons.name: Jane Norberg
persons.role: SEC Office of the Whistleblower Chief
persons.context: Primary recipient of the complaint. Dilorio is appealing a preliminary denial of his award claim to her office.

persons.name: Justin W. Keener
persons.context: Cited as a key figure in penny stock money laundering schemes, charged by the SEC in 2020. Dilorio claims he informed the SEC about Keener years prior.

persons.name: Dan Coleman
persons.role: CEO of KCG, former UBS Equities head
persons.context: Formerly ran Equities at UBS during Reg SHO violations; became CEO of KCG after its merger. Positioned as a central figure linking NITE/KCG and UBS in the alleged schemes.

persons.name: Sean McKessy
persons.context: Former head of the SEC Whistleblower Office. Dilorio corresponded with him and claims McKessy solicited more information after receiving his TCR.

persons.name: Robin Traxler
persons.context: FINRA official with whom Dilorio had extensive correspondence in 2012 regarding trading in shells like CGFIA and APCX.

persons.name: Carl Hoecker
persons.context: Current SEC IG accused by Dilorio of criminal obstruction for not properly investigating his complaints and not interviewing him.

persons.name: Steven Peikin
persons.context: Accused along with Clayton of having conflicts and not recusing themselves from matters involving NITE/Virtu.

persons.name: Jonathan New
persons.context: Former CFO of AQR/Crede, linked to Milken money laundering.

persons.name: Donald Engel
persons.context: Director of Blink who worked at Drexel with Michael Milken.

persons.name: Gregg Jaclin
persons.context: Attorney linked to a 'shell factory' and barred as an SEC lawyer.

persons.name: Terren Peizer
persons.context: Linked to Milken, Drexel, and entities like Crede and Net Element.

persons.name: Michael Wachs
persons.context: Felon partner of Peizer, linked to Net Element offerings.

persons.name: Martin Schlaff
persons.context: Austria/Israel-based controller of Alpha Capital Anstalt, linked to various shells and money laundering.

persons.name: Tom Priore
persons.context: CEO of PRTH (MI Acquisition), described as a well-known fraudster to the SEC.

persons.name: John McCarthy
persons.context: Former SEC NY official who ended up as Chief Counsel at Knight/KCG. Linked by Dilorio to SEC failures in the Madoff case.

persons.name: Luis A. Aguilar
persons.context: Co-authored a dissenting statement on the Oppenheimer waiver, citing 'billions' of shares traded, which Dilorio uses as evidence.

persons.name: Kara M. Stein
persons.context: Co-authored a dissenting statement on the Oppenheimer waiver with Commissioner Aguilar.

persons.name: Vikas Arora
persons.context: IRS Criminal Investigation agent who met with Dilorio in Denver in 2016 regarding his claims.

persons.name: Nathan Sarnacki
persons.context: IRS Criminal Investigation agent who met with Dilorio in Denver in 2016.

connections.description: Dilorio repeatedly sends allegations and appeals to Janey at the SEC, accusing Janey of failing to distribute his information and being part of the obstruction.
Former colleagues at the law firm Sullivan & Cromwell (Sull Crom); Dilorio alleges Fishman played a key role in fraud related to their client Knight/Virtu (NITE).
New is a Blackstone executive; both are implicated in the Kodak (KODK) loan and alleged fraud.
Former colleagues at the law firm Paul Weiss; Dilorio alleges this relationship creates a conflict of interest, with Mehraban obstructing investigations into Cifu's company, Virtu.
Described as 'BFFs'; connected through political donations and alleged collaborative grifts like the KODK deal.
Both are labeled 'bag men' and are involved in the same alleged money laundering shell company, Blink Charging (BLNK).
Urban was Trump's Pennsylvania campaign manager and is on the board of NITE, linking Trump's circle to the alleged financial fraud.
Mentioned as being 'connected to... Epstein' in the context of Schwarzman's high status and alleged immunity from investigation.
Linked to Epstein and his New Mexico ranch, and also involved with Blink Charging.
Dilorio is submitting a formal appeal and detailed complaint to Norberg, the SEC OWB Chief, regarding the denial of his whistleblower award.
Alleged to be the top two executing broker-dealers/market makers trading billions of shares in the same OTC money laundering shells (CGFIA, APCX, IMDS), facilitating the scheme.
Dilorio alleges NITE was the executing broker that converted Keener/JMJ's 'worthless certs' into real money through abusive naked shorting.
Dilorio claims NITE was a top trader in Sason/Hanover/Magna-related shells like NewLead and FreeSeas, converting worthless certificates.
Coleman ran the Equities division at UBS during the period of its Reg SHO violations and cross-border activity detailed in other complaints.
Dilorio's core allegation: The SEC has actively obstructed investigations, bailed out NITE after the 2012 'glitch', and facilitated its ongoing illegal activity to protect it.

events.title: Knight Capital Trading Glitch and Bailout
events.description: A software glitch at Knight Capital Group caused massive losses, dropping the stock from over $10 to nearly $2.50. The company was bailed out by a consortium including Blackstone, Goldman Sachs, Jefferies, and JPMorgan with a convertible deal at a deep discount.

events.title: Phlow Corporation Awarded $354M Government Contract
events.description: Phlow Corporation, a pharmaceutical manufacturer, received a $354 million contract from HHS/ASPR/BARDA to manufacture essential medicines, including the Trump-promoted hydroxychloroquine.

events.title: Kodak (KODK) Pharmaceutical Announcement and Stock Pump
events.description: President Trump announced Eastman Kodak would pivot to pharmaceutical ingredient manufacturing, causing the stock to soar from $2 to $90 before falling back. Dilorio alleges this was a pump-and-dump scheme with no substantive 8-K filing.

events.title: Blink Charging (BLNK) Press Release and Stock Jump
events.description: BLNK issued a press release about being awarded a grant to place charging stations, driving the stock up 27% on high volume. Dilorio alleges this was a fraudulent pump with no corresponding material 8-K filing.

events.title: Anthony Zakel Hired as DFC Inspector General
events.description: Anthony Zakel was hired as the first dedicated Inspector General for the U.S. International Development Finance Corporation (DFC).

events.title: Dilorio's Email Forward Regarding DFC IG and Kodak
events.description: Christopher Dilorio forwards emails alleging the DFC Inspector General's review of the $765 million Kodak loan is a foregone conclusion, akin to corrupt SEC IG investigations.

events.title: Dilorio's First Whistleblower Complaint
events.description: Christopher Dilorio files his first whistleblower complaint with the SEC, detailing massive fraud centered on Knight Capital (NITE) and UBS (UBSS).

events.title: Knight Capital 'Trading Glitch'
events.description: Knight Capital suffers a massive trading loss due to a software glitch. Dilorio alleges this event proved his prior claims of Knight's insolvency and involved Knight inadvertently sending 4000 worthless securities to JPMorgan as collateral.

events.title: Dilorio/Berger TCR Submission
events.description: Dilorio, with law firm Berger Montague, submits an amended TCR to the SEC detailing illegal activity by NITE and UBSS in shells like CGFIA and IMDS.

events.title: DTCC Global Lock on CGFIA
events.description: The DTCC imposes a 'Global Lock' on Colorado Goldfields Inc. (CGFIA) stock due to actions by a third-party broker-dealer, which Dilorio cites as clear evidence of naked shorting.

events.title: SEC Oppenheimer AML Action
events.description: The SEC brings an administrative proceeding against Oppenheimer & Co. for anti-money laundering failures (Covered Action 2015-016). Dilorio claims this action was based on his information but was incomplete.

events.title: IRS CI Meeting in Denver
events.description: IRS Criminal Investigation agents Vikas Arora and Nathan Sarnacki fly to Denver to meet with Dilorio regarding his claims.

events.title: Virtu Acquisition of KCG Closes
events.description: Virtu Financial completes its acquisition of KCG Holdings. Dilorio alleges this transaction was fraudulent, involved writing down billions in naked short fails, and was facilitated by SEC obstruction.

events.title: SEC Charges Joshua Sason et al.
events.description: The SEC charges Joshua Sason and others for roles in microcap frauds. Dilorio claims this was based on his earlier TCRs.

events.title: SEC Charges Justin Keener/JMJ
events.description: The SEC charges Justin W. Keener d/b/a JMJ Financial as an unregistered penny stock dealer. Dilorio claims he informed the SEC about Keener years prior.

events.title: Dilorio's Formal Appeal to SEC OWB
events.description: Christopher Dilorio sends this extensive email as a formal appeal of the SEC OWB's preliminary denial of his award claim for Covered Action 2015-016, detailing allegations of SEC obstruction and ongoing fraud.

locations: Santa Monica, California (HQ of New Concepts)
Jersey City (implied location of NITE/Virtu operations)
Denver, Colorado (location of CGFIA 'world HQ' and meeting with IRS CI)
Neuchatel, Switzerland (location connected to CGFIA CEO Guyer's previous endeavor)
Highlands Ranch, Colorado (location of Antelope Technologies office)
keyFacts: Christopher Dilorio, a self-proclaimed whistleblower, alleges a vast conspiracy of corruption and obstruction within the SEC, protecting powerful entities like Blackstone, Virtu Financial (NITE), and various 'bag men' involved in money laundering through OTC market shells.

He claims the SEC created a new whistleblower rule (Rule 240.21F-18) specifically to deny him an award by allowing denial if 'staff never saw' the information, which he dubs 'The Christopher J Dilorio Rule.'

Dilorio alleges Knight Capital/Virtu Financial's subsidiary NITE is perpetually insolvent due to its core business of 'abusive naked shorting' of OTC shells to facilitate money laundering, a fraud actively facilitated by the SEC.

He connects multiple financial and political figures, including Steve Schwarzman (Blackstone), Jared Kushner, Donald Trump, and Jeffrey Epstein, to alleged frauds such as the Eastman Kodak (KODK) loan and Blink Charging (BLNK).

The emails reference SEC officials (Jay Clayton, Lara Shalov Mehraban, Dick Best) having undisclosed conflicts of interest through former law firm colleagues (Sullivan & Cromwell, Paul Weiss) who represent or are involved with the entities under allegation.

The whistleblower, Christopher Dilorio, alleges the SEC has used his TCR information since 2011 to both bring enforcement actions (e.g., against Oppenheimer, Joshua Sason, Justin Keener) and to obstruct investigations, particularly those involving market maker Knight Capital/Virtu (NITE) and UBS (UBSS).

A core allegation is that NITE and UBSS are the primary executing brokers converting 'worthless certificates' from OTC shell companies (like CGFIA, APCX, IMDS) into real money through abusive naked shorting, facilitating a massive money laundering scheme.

Dilorio cites the DTCC's 2013 'Global Lock' on CGFIA stock as 'irrefutable evidence' of naked shorting by a third-party broker-dealer, which he implies is NITE, and questions why the SEC did not fully investigate this.

He accuses the SEC of criminal obstruction, specifically protecting NITE (e.g., via the 2012 'glitch' bailout) and UBSS, and alleges conflicts of interest involving SEC officials like Chairman Jay Clayton and former Enforcement officials.

The document claims the SEC Whistleblower Office denied Dilorio's award for the Oppenheimer action based on the false pretext that 'investigators never saw his information,' which he argues is the OWB's own responsibility to distribute.
